comments.body: You big brain bro üëç
This should definitely be in game. We surely need more use cases for Amethysts. I would like to try building redstone and cool looking laser shows. Please Mojang make it happen.
oohhh i remember a scene from Minecraft story mode I'm voting yes
Amazing! :D

I really like this idea, making it only obtainable mainly through archeological digs would give players more reason to engage with the new mechanic.

However, if I may suggest a couple of tweaks to this idea, I feel like tin should have at least one more use besides creating bronze and a block that creates a distraction for the Warden. Additionally, it could have an ore variant, but the catch is that tin ore would have about the same level of rareness as emerald ore. To add on to this rareness, tin ore could only be found under a specific biome, such as snowy tundra's or jungles. Doing this would encourage the player to go out into the unknown and explore their world. 

Overall this this is really good idea.

I agree, this would be a very nice step before iron and could give a nice progression that matches real life of the stone-age/leathers -> bronze age -> iron age.

I would love to see bronze armor derived from copper and tin, there are a large amount of roleplay resource packs and servers that would benefit from this as well.
Maybe instead of using the crafting table or anvil we can combine tin and copper in the smithing table kind of like netherite thus giving the smithing fable more use other than upgrading diamond gear

Honestly perfect way to make the current archeological system have beneficial non-rare item drops, and to finally top it off with a homage to the Bronze Age ‚Äî which I always felt was missing in this game. Could even be used as a way to stop copper block rust by just having bronze blocks instead, and I would absolutely love new bronze tools and armour, with reasoning being that copper by itself would rust too quickly.

One thing I would critique would be that even though bronze is technically harder than iron, utility-wise as tools and armour their weaknesses seem to balance each other out ‚Äî and the main drawback of bronze is that it‚Äôs components are much rarer than iron ore. But since you need a very high temperature furnace to smelt iron, why not make the blast furnace be necessary to smelt iron (and because it needs the high temperature, it takes the full 10 seconds to smelt like in a regular furnace), and then have the crafting recipe for the blast furnace require either iron ingots OR bronze ingots to be created. This way, the metals and how they were used reflect their actual properties and historical practise, there‚Äôs a clear developmental process reminiscent of the Stone, Bronze, and Iron Ages, and while similar to iron, bronze functions as more than just a cosmetic reskin of iron, give or take a bit of damage/hardness/etc.

Note: that‚Äôs just an idea, and if we were to implement it as well we‚Äôd need to change up iron farms (probably by turning all the iron ingots drops into iron ore block drops or something, and zombies rarely dropping iron nuggets instead of ingots), but I think this adds copper, tin and bronze accurately in a way that makes sense and makes them a significant step, but without deviating too much from the natural progression of the game. Also it maks iron ore a good learning tool for new players, encouraging players to keep the ore until it shortly becomes very useful

I agree with the idea from Rolough of having a tin ore, but making it rare, though maybe not as much quite so as emerald, but found in a larger range of height. The idea of having it spawn more frequently in some biomes is definitely something I agree with. As a suggestion, I would go with mountains, which are already being updated and which seem like the right kind of place to find it. The crying tin block is a nice idea, and the bronze is definite, but there should also be another use or two of it. Additionally, it could have a cut variant similar to copper, to allow for players to have tin roofs and such. As for the bronze alloy, I would suggest a new utility block for the purpose of making alloys, an alloy furnace. It would be crafted with iron (or bronze) on top and bottom, with the middle row being Blast Furnace, Hopper, Blast Furnace, making it the intense heating of two metals that are then combined. (i feel this recipe really makes sense.)

Finally and most importantly, get this post under the Caves And Cliffs category if possible, it will receive more attention. This must be added, it simply must,
Great idea, but I don‚Äôt think bronze should be stronger than iron, it should be a gap in between stone and iron.
This is a great way to implement Tin!

I agree tin makes sense to be added with copper to make bronze tools but I think it should be the tier between stone and iron but iron requires a harder to smelt and be effectively becomes steel so that it is better than bronze. Tin could also but used for pipes, as I've seen in another post, for hopper items. I think tin could be used to make "Tins" that is an item inventory like the bundle that can only carry food, maybe it can contain a couple more stacks just for food and you can just eat the "Tin" to consume the food on top of the pile much like you can only take the top item in a bundle. This means you can carry lots of different food you find and just much on one item.

I had the same idea about tin being added into Minecraft for the purpose of bronze. I was thinking how could bronze be crafted. Bronze during the Ancient Greek times was used a lot in armor and weaponry, especially spears and shield. So this is a great time to add spear made 3 diagonal ingots. And to make a bronze shield why not use the smithing table (the same thing to make netherite things). This will give more use to the block, since at the current moment it has little use. Bronze and Tin blocks will give us more building items. Also, Tins properties halt corrosion so maybe it can act like lapis in repairing armor and tools along with XP, maybe even for oxidized copper but wax is already a good solution for that. Tin is also used to make solder which is a fusible metal alloy used to create a permanent bond between metal workpieces, so that can change the daylight sensor recipe (maybe one tin ingot and 2 quartz?) And if heat was ever introduced into redstone, tin would be great for that. Now for bronze besides tools, would be a bunch of decorations such as cups, rails, window/door frames, and plaques. Also OP you should change this to ‚ÄúTin/Bronze‚Äù.
Nice idea
I would like to see tin because I'm building a duplicate of the house I live in and it has a tin roof.

I thought about the same thing and bronze can also be used to make bronze arrows which are stronger than just the regular arrow without effects and maybe you can make a spear or bronze shield to 1 up the regular shield. I thought of the exact same thing I also thought about the idea of having steele in the game which would be a in between of iron and diamond. The only thing I disagree with is that iron is stronger than bronze at least from what I know it's more durable and has a higher melting point than bronze meaning it's stronger I think it would be better if it was between stone and iron that way it would make more sense but it would have more crafting options that way there is a reason to go out of your way to get bronze ai also think one thing Minecraft needs along with this expansion would be the invention of the wheel because we have horses and having a wagon with a chest would be really cool in Minecraft it would feel like we would move through time periods and ages just like history and after all there are the achievements stone age and iron age I think it'll be cool if they had a bronze age.
A thought I had is that with tin you can have another rusting feature but also you could include sound for walking on it. "clack clack clack"
For those saying that Bronze should be worse than Iron, no. Bronze is generally better than Iron, at least better than the one used during the Iron age. STEEL is better than Bronze, tho.

i dont think that this will get implemented until lava becomes renewable, or it is a special kind of magma block that turns back into lava, because otherwise lava would become hard to get very quickly.
That would make building abandoned/decaying house look even cooler.

Maybe wooden type blocks that were on fire could just have a chance of becoming charred naturally; it would lend a lot more atmosphere to burnt out buildings and forest fires if there were actually charred remains leftover. It would also be an elegant way to add a new wood type.

Maybe with levels of charring based on time on fire until completely burned up. leaving an ember.

Additional nice little features it could have if they were so desired:

  • The hat could be dyed so you could make matching outfits with leather armor.
  • Like mobs heads, the hat could disguise you from witches, reducing detection by 50% of the normal range.
  • The hat could be place-able like mob heads (though this may be unnecessary considering armor stands)
How about if ware the hat and throw a potion at another entity it does twice the damage. (Or twice whatever the potion originally does. I idea is perfect.

I like the idea of the hat only giving magic protection and no protection from physical attack and villagers avoiding you while wearing one, though I'm not sold on the curses. Or at least the vanishing/binding curses. If Mojang wanted to make some other curses for the Witch Hats though, that'd be neat.
The Witch Hat should be the can head variant, only drop by killing with a charged creeper, and only grant 50% reduced detection.
This would be awesome!
I don't think it needs to have any special properties relating to potions or curses. Just being a cosmetic item, like the mob heads, would be a fun addition for players.

I love this idea, ESPECIALLY the effect on cats. Trying to get cats to slowly walk into the perfect position where I could tame them was always a pain for me, so having them not be afraid would be terrific! I agree with the 50% less detectability and the armor level as well, but I am not sure about the enchant-ability. I understand the reasoning that witches are magical so their hats should be magical too, but witches seem to mostly deal with potions instead of enchantments, so maybe it should have about the same enchant-ability as gold armor instead of having more.

A witch hat can reduce visability around illager type mobs or if placed on a villager using a dispenser, illagers won‚Äôt attack the villager, making the hat useful for helping villagers survive patrols or raids
i want that
How about it does two things. First, cats wont run away from you making it easy to tame them. Two, witches will not be hostile and you can trade with them. This would be a good way to get lapis.
Sounds like a good idea to me !
That's too easy to get you should have to find a really rare ore instead of iron nuggets but it still should be a thing. But it shouldn't be called that.
Good idea
I think it should be found in the depths of the end
ever since they added netherite people now want more armour sets WHAT IS THIS

I like the idea of crying obsidian working with water. What about this idea:

 

Crying obsidian acts like a water block in many ways. You can use it to irrigate farmland, fill bottles or damage fire entities. You can not extinguish entities with it to prevent the player to take it with them as a life saver.

What if placing water next to crying obsidian in the Nether converts it to some kind of special water that won't evaporate even if the crying obsidian is removed? 

If so, I could see this special stuff putting out fires, but not without a cost, as you would end up getting a random status effect (possibly even the wither effect) from coming into contact with it.  Furthermore you shouldn't be able to really swim in it- in fact, I'm thinking that it acts almost like an air block aside from actually flowing and being collectable like water...  I'm also thinking this stuff could also be used to brew luck-based potions...

If it were to be a permanent transformation then you would be able to reuse the same crying obsidian over and over, and because it‚Äôs as thick as lava you won‚Äôt be able to really swim in it. I do like the idea of brewing formerly unobtainable or new potions from the water however, and maybe you would need to craft a special bucket to carry it as well.

To be honest, @Samuel Miller, I really don't mind being able to use the same crying obsidian over and over as long as there's a relatively high cost for initiating the transformation- it should be something which quite frankly, is not easy to get ahold of.  The main reason for my suggesting it as a permanent transformation is that I don't want to have to constantly have to be involved in maintenance when I have other things and projects to work on in the Nether.

Perhaps I should also add that you would not be able to carry out the transformation of water into nether water in the Overworld, as such an attempt would fail.  Besides which, you would be risking the triggering of a reverse-beacon-slash-reverse-conduit-style death trap if my idea comes through- not that I'm opposed to your idea at all...

I do see how maintenance might be a problem, which is why I wouldn‚Äôt care if it was just the crying obsidian without needing fuel. About the permanent transformation though, the thing is Piglins can give up to 5 crying obsidian and I don‚Äôt want it to become obsolete for this purpose after only one. I would imagine the radius being at least a few blocks though, so you could cover a fairly large area and it won‚Äôt take a huge amount.

Truth be told, @Samuel Miller, even with a permanent transformation, you would still need to renew your supplies of the stuff over time, as nether water doesn't have an infinite source, just as lava doesn't.  Besides, what's wrong with potentially using crying obsidian for this purpose in large-scale builds?  Of course, without the crying obsidian, nether water's properties could be more along the lines of what I initially described in terms of it being virtually intangible (aside from flowing and being collectable with a bucket) and giving random status effects to mobs it comes into contact with; furthermore, it would be utterly useless for watering crops in that state.  So, the presence of crying obsidian would still be a must for both safety reasons and utility reasons, and, like we both seem to agree, its effects would have a limited radius.

Nether sprouts honestly sound like more of a wild nether plant, but that doesn't mean they can't drop the seeds of a farmable nether crop in the same way that grass drops wheat seeds in the Overworld.  Nether crops would be able to take and utilize nether water in its raw, dangerous form, though the resulting fruit would be unfit for eating. The effects of crying obsidian on nether water would in turn mean that the fruit of nether crops would be safe to eat, though for this to work, the crop would have to be supplied by nether water in its safest form from the moment it gets planted up until the fruit is produced.
I think that it should be a source block for a tear liquid that acts like water
Good idea, that's kind of what I was going for in a way.
How about having the crying obsidian drip water onto a leaf block that then slowly turns into a water source block that can flow, but will only work as water in the nether if you leave it there.
This is a great point that lava in the nether already has the same consistency of Overworld water so why not do the same for making it renewable?

This is excellent for the nether update! Lava buckets are used for smelting items, but they aren't stackable, making them difficult to be used for it. And the nether have too much lava! This isn't overpowered, I think.

Trading lava buckets aren't overpowered too, because the buckets disappear in the process.

I understand the idea for infinite lava sources, but I kind of get why they might not do it this way. Especially since obsidian is renewable, from piglin bartering, maybe this would be a good chance for a magic wand to come in. Maybe there could be a spell that dramatically heats up obsidian back into lava, so it would be like that's the only way for obsidian to get that hot to melt, and would keep other minecraft mechanics the same. This would make since, because people might abuse by just surrounding lava around to easily create more if the mechanics were similar to water, ( and lava is pretty powerful,) and people as a result might not have to come to the Nether as much. Maybe the spell could even only work in the Nether.

Cool idea. However, I am not too keen on the totem saving your life multiple times - that seems OP. I think Immortality should equate to different amounts of health the totem will restore to you at death.
If they could keep this balanced I would love to see this added! Possibly make it so Immortality gives the totem a damage bar or something?
How bout' the infinity enchantment for totems, infinite totem uses!!

Galiantus' idea is really cool, I think that's a more balanced way to do it. I don't think it should be farmable from villagers just because of the overpoweredness.

I think the idea should be simplified.

Same recipe as for Dropper, but instead of Cobblestone, use regular Stone.

This way the texture probably should be smoothed and lightened a little bit to match regular stone rather than cobblestone...

But we will get rid of unstackable part (Bow), and also we will not throw craft simplicity out of the window (like in this example where you have to connect bow recipe with dropper), while making it still harder to craft than Dropper.
I thought that they should just change the bow to string but this works too!

This is a really good idea. As it is, crafting tons of dispensers for one's project is really annoying. The experience doesn't add anything to the game. So making the recipe not involve bows, or any other unstackable item, would be a great change to the game. I think the recipe should be changed to either OP's idea, or swap the bow in the recipe to string.

How about sweet berries and a water bottle. Water bottles are pretty useless otherwise.

I don't think that it should heal you though. That is a bit OP. Maybe it is so cool and refreshing it reduces fire damage? Like a mini fire-resist pot for after you are on fire. It could be useful to take some to the nether.
Martin, thats not how juice works.
You ever made your own juice? Loads of fruits need water added to make juice. But this is not a cooking suggestions site.

I have a bone to pick with the instant regeneration. It‚Äôs quite over the top for something so available. This should really just be used so we don‚Äôt waste as much time eating. I am currently making a survival vineyard but haven‚Äôt really relied on the berries because they take so long to consume and fill my inventory.
How about a speed boost? It needs a benefit otherwise it wont be worth making

I like it filling two drumsticks of hunger, but here's a hot take:

Sweet Berry Juice (or Jam; depends on how you look at it) should cure Slowness.

Think about how useful that is:
Sweet berries are found in Taiga biomes, which are usually nearby colder biomes.
What mob commonly spawns in cold biomes? Strays.
What do Strays attack with? Tipped Arrows of Slowness.

I like the idea of cheaper, alternative medicines (like Honey curing poison), so I think this is a nice fit. Maybe only 4 berries and 1 bottle make 1 juice though; I dunno. That might make it too easy to craft?

I would like it to be wine colour so that people could rename it to tell stories about vineyards, wineries, inns and such, but at the same time it's not like having actual wine in the game. I would also like if you could drink it regardless of your hunger bar, just like you can sip some wine. Also, but maybe it's asking too much, it could have some effect like make you dizzy for some seconds or minutes.

For what concerns the crafting, I'd say a water bottle + berries + sugar might be fine.

If we want to really expand on this idea, we could introduce a mechanic called fermentation that could allow us to use that to craft some particular items, like a substitute crafting for the fermented spider eye and possibly new sort of magical items. Imagine for example a fermented chorus fruits that teleports you farther or maybe more times altogether. This could open to some nice ideas.
You can do this already. Put in multiple dyes in the crafting table and put the leather armor in the recipe. There are over a million color choices to choose from.
no 1 mean on banners

As an extra comment, it would also be cool if you can enchant a sheep, maybe have to give it a special item or something and it becomes a more specific color.

It could be x1.3 or x1.5, x2 is too op.
I think making the composter useful might be a higher priority, but I still like your idea. Voted.
Fish literally was one of the first things taught to the Europeans on how to grow crops faster... Definitely needs to have fish added to the options.  Maybe at the same level as baked potato?

I love this idea because it makes not only the composter, but a bunch of other items so much more useful. Got a bunch of rotten flesh you will never use for anything? chuck it into the composter. Caught thirty of each type of fish while you were trying to catch a mending book? they could all go in the composter.

I do love the composter as a block, but I have to admit it's not super useful right now

Exactly! And people often put meat scraps into real composters, so why not?

Edit: I think eggs, poisonous potatoes and mob drops like spider eyes should also be put in the composter. (They're all organic materials.)
...or it lasts for only a few hits, based on the sword material? I agree. That would make preparing for important fights much more interesting.

I knew someone had to have posted this already! I love this idea, especially with some of the potion ideas I've seen suggested on here. Someone suggested a leeching potion (go check that out too, it's pretty cool) and I think this would go great with that. Although, I wonder... it takes three potions to fill a cauldron. Would dipping your sword only take up one potion, thus meaning you could dip your sword three times before having to refill? Or would it use all three at once?

Great idea and would take it a bit further...the engine block should be available for other modes of transportation such as boats, airplanes, helicopters, submarines and elevators. I've imagined building a giant city-ship that could explore the oceans and carry an airplane, helicopter, submarine and automobile on board for furter exploration.
This sounds really cool and I feel like should be in Minecraft

The wheel should be able to be powered by red stone so that you can build a car, and you should also be able to make a cart pulled by horse, llama, or mule. And yes, we should have the steering wheel too.

This this is a fantastic idea. You are spot on! This is a very good idea as an example. I‚Äôd love to be able to build a flying house, UFO, etc in survival mode and creative mode. Currently I have an airport that I wish I could get my planes to fly and be flown around to different airports. Yes that would be cool. Imagine taking passengers around the map.

I have been kicking this idea around for a while now. I would like to suggest in addition to the fine ideas here that the engine block only work when attached to blocks that have been gathered by a player and not attached to the ground (unless wheel blocks become a thing).  The engine block should be harder to make and perhaps use Redstone, Iron blocks, and Copper blocks in its construction.  If it were up to me, I would make the ratio of 1 engine block per 64 blocks you would like to move.  I think it would be amazing to be able to craft a working zeppelin or even a floating castle :) Perhaps a "helm" block to keep multiple people from driving the same craft at once in multiplayer.  You could also maybe make the Engine block consume Redstone as fuel (much like a furnace consumes coal).   If you wanted, you could set a certain speed the craft can go based on the ratio of blocks to engine block (I.E) if its velocity is 4 blocks/sec at 64 blocks then it could be 8 blocks/sec at 32 blocks and fastest at 16 blocks/sec with a ratio of 1 engine on a 16-block vehicle.  Just some thoughts.  I love the engine block idea!!!!
this would be nice, i think. if you want more inspiration check out my post about the engine: https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/23373530709517-Engine-and-cannon-by-dragonpie646

Make the cursed diamonds a magical ore that you can use to make a diamond magical wand. You can use the wand to fly, turn invisible and many more. I like this idea.  Although I assume it would be already explored end cities so that ones that haven't been loaded yet don't get an explosion of shulkers when they're first generated?
Very handy, I will say. But I like it! Also I think shulker boxes are added in 1.11.
Very true. This needs to be a feature, but I aggree with @ClayGoddessSari

There was a great suggestion to this problem on Reddit once upon a time... maybe it was you that suggested it!

It was to have all or a portion of the shulkers in End Citys respawn when ever the Dragon is killed. This would preserve the valuable/rarity of shulker boxes, but would also promote exploration of the end. It would also promote repeat battles with the Dragon. For players on a local single play world, shulker quantity isn't really an issue, but on a multiplayer realm/server it has become an almost instant issue. This would be the most elegant way to resolve this problem without creating a "farm-able" shulker.

I think it'd be more in the realm of minecraft that when you kill the dragon, the crystal pedestals would each have a low chance at spawning a shulker on top of it, that way you wouldn't have to worry about loading all the end cities, checking which ones have been cleared, and it'd still be difficult to get renewable boxes

Shulker boxes should definitely be renewable, not only are they hard to come by in singleplayer but the situations even worse in multiplayer. Also if the skulkers / shells get destroyed or fall into the void, that's them lost forever.

I saw an implementation of this in a mod where endermites would behave like silverfish and burro into Purpur blocks, turning that block into a Shulker.
I have made it where when the dragon is defeated in my mod, it spawns 8-16 shulkers around the exit portal.

Am late to the party? I'm 5 years late, wow. Your request has been granted! Shulker boxes can now duplicate. Shulker farms are now available in all versions of minecraft. Shulker duplication was added in java in 1.17 and in bedrock 1.19. Shulker boxes now have a chance to duplicate if hitten by another shulker. I will now leave, bye!
